title: GM's (GM) New Diesel Engine Enters the Fray Amid Broad Public Censure for VW - TheStreet
text:
Reddit Email Print Reprint NEW YORK (TheStreet) -- For Volkswagen ( VLKAY ) , it's the worst of times thanks to its diesel engines, as the automaker suffers self-inflicted global wounds resulting from doctored software and falsified emission testing.
For General Motors ( GM - Get Report ) , the controversy swirling around VW may turn out to be an auspicious moment to introduce the 2016 GMC Canyon mid-size pickup truck, which is powered by a 2.8-liter turbodiesel engine. For GM, it's a chance to prove that a diesel engine can save fuel -- legally.
The new Canyon, and its twin, the Chevrolet Colorado, have been selling briskly as part of GM's strategy to create additional product segments in the truck category, where the automaker earns the bulk of its profit.

Since late August, GM shares have been trending upward, rising in value about 12%. The current price of just more than $33 is roughly equal to the initial public offering price from late 2010.
Tightening fuel-efficiency regulations compels GM and other automakers to develop high-mileage fuel choices as alternatives to gasoline such as electric, gas-electric hybrids and diesel. Naturally, the alternatives must comply with emissions and all other regulations.
The Canyon's turbodiesel -- which averaged just less than 33 miles per gallon of diesel fuel during a trip along the Hudson River from Manhattan to Duchess County -- is just such an alternative. The diesel Canyon, which also is available with either a 2.5-liter four-cylinder or 3.6-liter six cylinder gasoline engine, was responsive and smooth, if somewhat noisy.
The Environmental Protection Agency hasn't yet issued official mileage ratings for the new engine. But the gasoline equivalents average roughly 25 miles per gallon of fuel, depending on city or highway, two or four-wheel-drive and size of engine.
I asked Jeff Luke, executive chief engineer for GM trucks, if the latest uproar surrounding VW on the subject of diesels had made him wary or nervous about the possibility of getting tripped up on regulations, even inadvertently.
"Not at all," Luke said. "We check and double check."
GM's 2.8-liter diesel is equipped with a special reservoir for urea (a substance similar to ammonia) that removes nitrogen oxide pollutants that are prevalent in diesel emissions. VW's diesels purported to meet emission standards without a urea reservoir, which adds cost and must be refilled every 7,500 miles or so.
In case an owner is delinquent about refilling Canyon's urea reservoir, a dashboard display will flash a warning. Then the vehicle's speed will be progressively limited until it's not driveable. Clearly, GM is taking pains not to avoid regulatory censure of the type that's engulfing VW.
GM's new diesel engine, imported from a plant in Thailand, was introduced during a promotional campaign to bring more attention to the GMC division -- one of the four in the U.S., along with Buick, Chevrolet and Cadillac, that survived the automaker's bankruptcy and reorganization. GMC brand promises a premium and design-oriented flavor to several truck and crossover models at a slightly higher price point than Chevrolet.
 
 
 
 
 
Doron Levin is the host of "In the Driver Seat" on SiriusXM, Insight 121, which is broadcast on Saturday at noon, repeating at 9 a.m. on Sunday.

The writer has no financial interest in the aforementioned companies.
